sub_topic: Using the law of sines to solve triangles
message_1: A triangle has one angle measuring 30° and another angle measuring 60°. The length of the side opposite the 30° angle is 10 units and the length of the side opposite the 60° angle is 15 units. Find the length of the remaining side, opposite the remaining angle.
message_2:
Since the sum of the angles in a triangle is always 180°, the remaining angle is 180° - 30° - 60° = 90°. This means we have a 30-60-90 right triangle.

In a 30-60-90 triangle, the side lengths are in the ratio 1:√3:2. Since the side opposite the 30° angle is 10 units, we can set up the following proportion:

1 / 10 = √3 / 15

Now, we can find the length of the side opposite the 90° angle (the hypotenuse) by using the ratio:

1 / 10 = 2 / x

Cross-multiplying, we get:

x = 20

So, the length of the remaining side, opposite the 90° angle, is 20 units.
